metadata.title: Preparation of linear low-density polyethylene from ethylene by tandem catalysis of iron and titanium non-metallocene catalysts

IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 8946 S1381-1169(13)00446-9 10.1016/j.molcata.2013.11.024 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Typical distribution of oligomers catalyzed by 1/MMAO (Run 2 in Table 1). Fig. 2 Typical 13C NMR spectrum of the LLDPE by 1/2/MMAO tandem system (Run 3 in Table 2). Fig. 3 Effects of reaction conditions on 13C NMR spectra of LLDPE: (a) Fe/Ti molar ratio and (b) Al/(Fe+Ti) molar ratio. Fig. 4 DSC thermograms for LLDPE under different conditions: (a) effect of Fe/Ti molar ratio and (b) effect of Al/(Fe+Ti) molar ratio. Fig. 5 Effects of different conditions on GPC curves for LLDPE: (a) Fe/Ti molar ratio and (b) reaction temperature. Fig. 6 Effects of reaction temperature and MMAO usage on distributions of α-olefins in oligomer and branches in LLDPE, (a) effect of temperature on distributions of α-olefins, (b) effect of temperature on distributions of branches, N ′ E , N ′ B and N ′ L refer to the number of ethyl, butyl and long chain branches, respectively, (c) effect of MMAO usage on distributions of α-olefins and (d) effect of MMAO usage on distributions of branches. Preparation of linear low-density polyethylene from ethylene by tandem catalysis of iron and titanium non-metallocene catalysts Guangyong Xie a b ⁎ Xiang Zhang a Tingcheng Li a Long Li a Gongyi Liu a Aiqing Zhang a ⁎⁎ a Key Laboratory of Catalysis and Materials Science of the State Ethnic Affairs Commission and Ministry of Education, Hubei Province, South-Central University for Nationalities, Wuhan 430074, China Key Laboratory of Catalysis and Materials Science of the State Ethnic Affairs Commission and Ministry of Education, Hubei Province, South-Central University for Nationalities Wuhan 430074 China b Ministry of Education Key Laboratory for the Green Preparation and Application of Functional Materials, Hubei University, Wuhan 430062, China Ministry of Education Key Laboratory for the Green Preparation and Application of Functional Materials, Hubei University Wuhan 430062 China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Key Laboratory of Catalysis and Materials Science of the State Ethnic Affairs Commission and Ministry of Education, Hubei Province, South-Central University for Nationalities, Wuhan 430074, China. Tel.: +86 27 67842752; fax: +86 27 67842752. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 27 67843192. Graphical abstract A non-metallocene titanium complex of β-carbonylenamine derived [O−NS]TiCl3 (2), which can form a tandem catalytic system with difluoro-substituted 2,6-bis(imino)pyridyl iron complex (1), was firstly used as in situ copolymerization catalyst to prepare linear low-density polyethylene (LLDPE) with ethylene as the sole monomer stock and MMAO as the only cocatalyst. During the reaction, 1/MMAO oligomerized ethylene to linear α-olefins with high activity and selectivity, while 2/MMAO copolymerized ethylene with the in situ generated α-olefins to LLDPE with high activity (up to 6×106 g/molTihatm). The influences of reaction conditions upon catalytic activity and polymer structures and properties have been researched. The polymers were characterized by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), high temperature gel permeation chromatography (GPC) and high temperature 13C NMR spectroscopy and proved to be LLDPE with ethyl, butyl as well as longer branches. The branching degrees were tuned efficiently from 4.6 to 39.3/1000C by different reaction conditions such as reaction temperature, Fe/Ti molar ratio and Al/(Fe+Ti) molar ratio. The melting points, degree of crystallinity and molecular weights also changed correspondingly with reaction conditions. Keywords Tandem catalysis In situ copolymerization Linear low-density polyethylene Non-metallocene Branching degree 1 Introduction Linear low-density polyethylene (LLDPE) is an important member of the family of polyethylenes which has better mechanical strength and processability than high-density polyethylene (HDPE) due to the presence of short-chain branches. Typically, LLDPE is obtained by ethylene copolymerization with α-olefin comonomers, such as 1-butene, 1-hexene, and 1-octene with Ziegler–Natta catalysts or recently developed single-site catalysts. However, α-olefins is commonly produced by oligomerization of ethylene. So the production of LLDPE requires integrating two different processes operating at different conditions: one is the oligomerization of ethylene to produce α-olefin comonomers, and the other is the copolymerization of ethylene with the produced α-olefin. LLDPE can also be prepared from ethylene-only stock in a single reactor since both stages use the same monomer, which is well known as tandem catalysis and attracted great interest due to its obvious advantages over the commonly used two-stage process in the costs of plant investment, α-olefin purification, storage, and transport. Tandem catalysis, which was first reported by Beach and Kissin in the 1980s [1], is also called in situ copolymerization and involves the cooperative action of oligomerization and copolymerization catalyst precursors in one reactor. Generally, four strategies can be used to produce branched polyethylene including LLDPE with ethylene as the sole monomer in a single reactor. The first one uses a single catalytic system comprising only one metal complex and one co-catalyst [2–4]. For example, nickel-diimine complexes are efficient in producing LLDPE with short-chain branched (SCB) structures through a catalytic mechanism called chain walking [2]. However, these catalysts produce PE with uncontrolled and randomly distributed short-chain branches (SCB) with predominantly methyl branches [3], and this makes it unsuitable for replacing conventional high α-olefin LLDPE. The second method adopts one catalyst precursor and two types of activators [5,6]. However, few catalyst precursors can be activated by different cocatalysts to provide the tandem catalytic system and it is also difficult to tune the structure of the obtained polyethylene. The third approach involves two catalyst precursors activated with two different co-catalysts [7]. Generally, such catalytic systems presented some problems like the interferences between the oligomerization catalyst and copolymerization catalyst, the catalysts and activators, and moreover, inferior control over the distribution of α-olefin and branching degree of the LLDPE obtained. The last strategy utilizes two or three catalyst precursors activated with only one activator [8], which is the most common method to prepare branched polyethylene since the structure of polymers produced by such in situ copolymerization can be regulated by the ratio of the oligomerization and polymerization catalysts and the reaction conditions. Fe or Cr complexes can be employed as oligomerization catalyst precursors, and metallocenes as the copolymerization precatalysts with MAO or B(C6F5)3 as the only co-catalyst. The catalytic systems employed in the latter three methods are also called dual-functional tandem catalytic systems and generally use Ziegler–Natta or metallocene catalysts as the copolymerization catalysts. In recent years, a great amount of research has been devoted to the development of group 4 non-metallocene catalysts for the controlled synthesis of polyolefin products [9]. Some of these catalysts exhibit good catalytic performances not only for ethylene polymerization but also for copolymerization of ethylene and α-olefin [10,11]. However, up to now, no literature on binary catalyst systems for ethylene using group 4 non-metallocene as copolymerization catalysts was reported. Here we described for the first time the direct synthesis of LLDPE from ethylene in a single reactor by a tandem iron (1) and titanium (2) non-metallocene dual-functional catalyst, which is shown in Scheme 1 . 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All work involving air- and/or moisture-sensitive compounds was carried out with standard Schlenk techniques. Toluene was distilled from sodium benzophenone ketyl under nitrogen. MMAO (7% aluminum in a heptane solution) was purchased from Akzo Nobel Chemical Inc. All other commercial chemicals are used as received. Fe complex [12(a)] and Ti complex [11(g),11(h)] were prepared in good yields according to the literature. 2.2 Characterization The 1H NMR spectra of ligands and compounds were recorded on a Bruker Avance III 400MHz spectrometer with tetramethylsilane as an internal standard. Elemental analyses were carried out using Vario EL 111. Analysis of α-olefin oligomers was performed by gas chromatography (SHIMADZUGC-17A ATF), using an Alpha-Col AC10 column (30m×0.32mm) and a FID detector. The injector and detector temperature was maintained at 250°C. The program was set with an initial temperature of 30°C (hold 5min), finishing temperature 220°C (hold 10min), and a heating rate of 10°C/min. The 13C NMR data of the ethylene/α-olefin copolymers were obtained on a Varian XL 300MHz spectrometer at 120°C with o-C6D4Cl2 as the solvent. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements were performed on a Perkin-Elmer Pyris 1 differential scanning calorimeter. Each sample was heated from 30 to 200°C at a heating rate of 10°C/min and reheated at the same rate. The M n and M w/M n of the polymers were determined at 150°C with a PL-GPC 220 high-temperature chromatograph using a polystyrene calibration. 1,2,4-Trichlorobenzene was employed as the solvent at a flow rate of 1.0mL/min. 2.3 Oligomerization procedure A flame-dried Schlenk flask was twice purged with N2 and charged with ethylene. The desired amount of freshly distilled toluene was transferred into the flask (placed in an oil bath at a desired temperature), and was saturated with ethylene. MMAO were injected into the flask using a syringe and the mixture was stirred for 5min. The oligomerization was started by adding a precursor catalyst solution in toluene with a syringe. After a desired time, the reaction solution was quickly cooled down to −20°C and then quenched with 5ml 5% dilute hydrochloric acid. After washed by water and dried by Na2SO4, the organic compounds were characterized by gas chromatography and GC–MS to determine the composition and molar mass distribution. 2.4 Ethylene polymerization and in situ copolymerization A procedure similar to the oligomerization was used. For the ethylene polymerization, only the solution of polymerization catalyst was added to the reactor. For the in situ copolymerization, the solutions of oligomerization and copolymerization catalysts were added at the same time. After a desired time, the polymerization was quenched with acidified ethanol (100mL, 10vol.% HCl in ethanol). The precipitated polymer was filtered off, washed with ethanol, and then dried under vacuum overnight at 50°C to constant weight. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Ethylene oligomerization with iron catalyst 2,6-Bis(imino)pyridyl iron complexes activated by MMAO can be used as ethylene oligomerization catalysts to obtain linear α-olefins with high activity [13]. Among them difluoro-substituted 2,6-bis(imino)pyridyl iron complex (1) reported by Qian et al. [12] is one of the most active and selective iron-based ethylene oligomerization catalysts with MMAO as cocatalyst. The influences of reaction temperatures and Al/Fe molar ratio upon catalytic activities and oligomer distributions are researched, and the results are listed in Table 1 . The 1/MMAO has high oligomerization activity with high selectivity for linear α-olefins. The typical distribution of oligomers catalyzed by 1/MMAO (Run 2 in Table 1) is shown in Fig. 1 . The activity can reach 1.54×106 g/molFehatm at 25°C and an Al/Fe ratio of 2000 under 1 atmosphere pressure. The reaction temperature has a great effect on the catalytic activity and the distributions of α-olefins. The activity increased to a maximum from 0 to 25°C, then decreased as temperature rose further to 50°C (Runs 1–3 of Table 1). However, the contents of low carbon constituents including 1-butene and 1-hexene in α-olefins continuously increased with the increase of temperature and at the same time the contents of high carbon ones decreased. The usage of MMAO has a minor effect on catalytic activity, but has a significant impact on oligomer distribution. The increase of Al/Fe molar ratio lowered the content of 1-butene in α-olefins yet increased the proportions of C6 and C8+ (Runs 2, 4 and 5 of Table 1). This change of the constituents in α-olefins would also influence the proportions of different branches in the copolymerized LLDPE. 3.2 In situ copolymerization of ethylene with iron and titanium catalysts LLDPE can be prepared efficiently by tandem catalysis with bisiminopyridyl iron complex (1) and non-metallocene titanium complex (2) as dual-functional catalysts and ethylene as the only stock. The effects of the reaction temperature, Fe/Ti and Al/(Fe+Ti) molar ratios on the copolymerization activities and properties of the copolymers are researched. The branching degrees, molecular weights and melting temperatures are measured by 13C NMR, GPC and DSC, respectively. The results are summarized in Table 2 . It can be found that the melting temperature (T m) and crystallinity of the copolymers catalyzed by 1/2/MMAO decreased compared with those of the polymers catalyzed exclusively by 2/MMAO, which implied that higher amount of α-olefins were produced and incorporated in the main chain. The high temperature 13C NMR spectrum further confirmed the branching structure (Fig. 2 ), and the branching degrees are determined accordingly. According to ref. [8(f)], the presence of ethyl branches are indicated by the resonances at δ 11.19ppm, δ 26.95ppm, and δ 39.97ppm, the butyl branches at δ 23.36ppm and δ 29.57ppm, and the longer branches (n ≥6) at δ 13.94ppm, δ 22.82ppm, δ 32.19ppm, and δ 38.45ppm. The 13C NMR spectrum showed that the obtained polyethylene was LLDPE with various branches, including ethyl, butyl, and longer branches. Further more, the branching degrees and branching structures could be tuned efficiently by reaction conditions. 3.2.1 Influence of Fe and Ti catalyst molar ratio A clear change in activity with different Fe/Ti molar ratios was observed, as seen from Runs 1 to 5 of Table 2. The activity increased from 1.67×106 to 6.04×106 g/molTihatm when the Fe/Ti molar ratio increased from 0:1 to 4:1, which may be explained by a positive comonomer effect. More α-olefins would be produced with more oligomerization catalyst added, thus leads to higher calculated activities for Ti complex. These results are similar to the copolymerization of ethylene and α-olefin catalyzed only by Ti complex reported by Tang's group [11h]. Fig. 3a shows the high temperature 13C NMR spectra of obtained polymers with different catalyst ratios. It can be found that the polymer produced by Ti complex exhibits only a single peak, typical of the main chain of HDPE. Whereas branching peaks, including those of ethyl, butyl, and longer branches which are characteristic of LLDPE are observed when Fe and Ti catalysts are used together. The branching degrees calculated from 13C NMR spectra increased from 0 to a maximum of 15.6/1000C as Fe/Ti molar ratio increased from 0:1 to 2:1, then decreased slightly to 14.3/1000C when the ratio increased to 4:1 (Runs 1–5 of Table 2). This may be a result of the strong positive comonomer effect, which stems from a faster increase of the activity of Ti complex than that afforded by the increased amount of Fe oligomerization catalyst. For example, when the molar ratio was increased from 2:1 to 4:1, the amount of oligomerization catalyst was increased twofold, yet the activity of copolymerization catalyst was increased 2.11 times (Runs 3 and 5 of Table 2). From DSC data in Fig. 4a, it can be found that the T m's of the produced LLDPE decreased substantially from 136.7°C to 112.8°C as the Fe/Ti molar ratio increased from 0:1 to 2:1. This is not unexpected since as more oligomerization catalyst (the Fe complex 1) is added, more α-olefins will be produced and incorporated into the polymer backbone, hence the increase of branching degree and the decrease of crystallinity. When the Fe/Ti molar ratio increased further to 3:1 and 4:1, the T m's however increased a little instead, suggesting a decrease of branching degree. These results are consistent with the 13C NMR spectra. In addition, apparent double melting peaks are observed with a Fe/Ti molar ratio of 3:1 and 4:1, and in the other cases they may also be present, just that they are too close to see clearly. It is possible that the Ti pre-catalyst forms two active species of a similar nature when it reacts with MMAO. These two species react slightly differently with the formed oligomers and produce copolymers of a slightly different composition melting at slightly different temperatures. This also is probably why the M w/M n ratio is higher than 2.0. Another possible reason may be attributed to the change of relative concentration of comonomers during the reaction, which would lead to the formation of mixtures of polyethylenes with different branching. A similar phenomenon has been reported in the literature [7(f),8(k),8(s)]. The molecular weight distribution (MWD) curves of polymers produced in different Fe/Ti ratios are shown in Fig. 5a. The copolymers have lower weight–average molecular weights than that of the homo-PE produced with 2/MMAO under the same reaction conditions due to the incorporation of α-olefins. 3.2.2 Influence of reaction temperature The polymerization temperature influences greatly not only the catalytic activities but also the structure of polymers. From Runs 3, 6 and 7 of Table 2, when the reaction temperature increased from 0 to 50°C, the copolymerization activities increased to a maximum at 25°C and then decreased, so did the branching degrees. On one hand, the Ti complex itself has the highest copolymerization activity at 25°C, on the other hand, largest amount of oligomers would be produced by Fe complex at 25°C, which would augment the copolymerization activity due to the positive comonomer effect. The polymer produced at 25°C also has lowest T m and crystallinity compared with those made at 0 and 50°C. The branching degree was 15.6/1000C at 25°C, but decreased at either higher or lower temperature. These results indicate that the two catalysts have better match and synergy at room temperature than at other temperatures. The GPC curves of copolymers at different polymerization temperatures are shown in Fig. 5b. Enhancing the temperatures from 0 to 50°C decreased rapidly the M w from 23.71×104 g/mol to 0.97×104 g/mol but increased the MWD from 1.93 to 3.21. Fig. 6b exhibits the percentage of different branches among total branches. The proportions of ethyl branches are between 40% and 70%, and higher temperature would result in higher proportions of ethyl branches and lower amount of longer branches, which is also in agreement with the changing of the distribution of α-olefins produced by Fe catalyst at corresponding temperatures (Fig. 6a). In addition, the proportion of ethyl branches is more than the content of 1-butene in α-olefins at the same reaction temperature, which illustrates that short chain 1-butene has higher reactivity than the other longer chain α-olefins and is much easier to insert into the main chain. 3.2.3 Influence of Al/(Fe+Ti) molar ratio The molar ratio of Al/(Fe+Ti) also has a significant effect on the catalytic activities as well as the polymer structures. As the Al/(Fe+Ti) ratio increased from 500 to 2000, the activity of the oligomerization catalyst was almost unchanged (Table 1), but the activity of the copolymerization catalyst increased, as did the in situ copolymerization activity. Because the amounts of the comonomers afforded by oligomerization were almost the same, the average branching degrees of the resulting products would decrease, as presented in Table 2. Fig. 3b shows the high temperature 13C NMR spectra of polymers obtained at different Al/(Fe+Ti) ratios, from which it can be found that the intensity of branches decreased as the Al/(Fe+Ti) ratio increased. A calculation revealed that the branching degree lowered gradually from 39.3 to 15.6/1000C along with the increase of Al/(Fe+Ti) ratio. Fig. 6c shows the distributions of α-olefin in oligomers with different usages of MMAO, and the percentage of different branches is presented in Fig. 6d. The two figures demonstrate a similar change but higher proportions of ethyl branches relative to long branches are present in polymers. The amount of MMAO introduced into the reaction system can also influence the thermal properties of polymers. Fig. 4b displays the DSC thermograms of a series of copolymers produced with different amounts of MMAO. The sample exhibited a broad melting endotherm and a small degree of crystallinity at Al/(Fe+Ti) ratio of 500, suggesting the presence of greater proportion of branches, which would inhibit the rearrangement of molecular-chains and growth of larger crystals. The T m's and degrees of crystallinity increased however as increasing the Al/(Fe+Ti) ratio, which indicated a reduction of branching degrees. These results are fully consistent with 13C NMR characterization. 4 Conclusions Two non-metallocene catalysts, β-carbonylenamine derived [O−NS]TiCl3 (2)/MMAO and difluoro-substituted 2,6-bis(imino)pyridyl Fe (1)/MMAO, form a tandem catalytic system for the first time to in situ copolymerize ethylene to linear low-density polyethylene (LLDPE). During the reaction, 1/MMAO oligomerizes ethylene to linear α-olefins, while 2/MMAO copolymerizes ethylene with the in situ generated α-olefins to LLDPE with high activity up to 106 g/molTihatm. The polymerization conditions influence greatly not only the catalytic activities but also the structure of polymers. The Ti complex (2) shows a strong positive comonomer effect for the activity. The polymers were characterized in detail by DSC, high temperature GPC and high temperature 13C NMR spectroscopy and proved to be LLDPE with various branches, including ethyl, butyl and longer branches. The reaction conditions can change the constituents in α-olefins produced by 1/MMAO as well as the proportions of different branches in the copolymerized LLDPE. Further more, the branching degrees can be tuned efficiently from 4.6 to 39.3/1000C by varying reaction temperature, Fe/Ti or Al/(Fe+Ti) molar ratios. The melting points, crystallinity and molecular weights of the products can also be modified accordingly. coredata.dc:description: A non-metallocene titanium complex of β-carbonylenamine derived [O−NS]TiCl3 (2), which can form a tandem catalytic system with difluoro-substituted 2,6-bis(imino)pyridyl iron complex (1), was firstly used as in situ copolymerization catalyst to prepare linear low-density polyethylene (LLDPE) with ethylene as the sole monomer stock and MMAO as the only cocatalyst. During the reaction, 1/MMAO oligomerized ethylene to linear α-olefins with high activity and selectivity, while 2/MMAO copolymerized ethylene with the in situ generated α-olefins to LLDPE with high activity (up to 6×106 g/molTihatm). The influences of reaction conditions upon catalytic activity and polymer structures and properties have been researched. The polymers were characterized by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), high temperature gel permeation chromatography (GPC) and high temperature 13C NMR spectroscopy and proved to be LLDPE with ethyl, butyl as well as longer branches. The branching degrees were tuned efficiently from 4.6 to 39.3/1000C by different reaction conditions such as reaction temperature, Fe/Ti molar ratio and Al/(Fe+Ti) molar ratio. The melting points, degree of crystallinity and molecular weights also changed correspondingly with reaction conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation of linear low-density polyethylene from ethylene by tandem catalysis of iron and titanium non-metallocene catalysts
